Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation2: A cruising aircraft simply requests the routine altimeter setting.
Story: My phone buzzed with a text from my younger sister: “Hey, are you coming to dinner tonight? Everyone’s asking about you.” I glanced at the clock—just past six. I’d promised her I’d make more of an effort, that I’d show up, be present, not just the sister who’s always too busy. But the headset pressed against my ear, and the radar screen glowed with a steady stream of blips. “Approach, Delta 452, request altimeter setting,” crackled through my headset. My job demanded my full attention; a single distraction could mean disaster. I felt the weight of both worlds—my family expecting me to be there, to laugh and share stories, and the pilots relying on my calm, precise instructions. My heart thudded as I stared at my phone, torn between the warmth of my sister’s invitation and the cold, unwavering responsibility of the airspace under my watch. I hesitated, caught in the impossible space between being the sister I wanted to be and the controller I had to be.
